content.description:
P1: As for Shit-Hawk

P2: Enjoyable laybacking and stemming up a prominent feature. Gear is quite good and climbing is much easier than it looks. Follow the crack up and left to find the belay recessed on the ledge above.



From the first pitch anchor of Shit-Hawk, move the belay down the ledge and climb the hand crack in the obvious right facing corner to a small roof.

Single rack to 3"

climbs.name: Set the Controls for the Heart of the Sun

content.description:
Well protected and reasonably safe, but expect moderate run-outs between bolts, with some mandatory small gear placements. Bolted on lead so bolts generally appear after the cruxes, not before or during.

Start as for Space Quest, but climb just inside the chimney before breaking right and following bolts up the obvious shallow corner.
6 bolts and some small gear to 0.5", to rings on the large ledge climbers right

P1: Climb the obvious crack on the right side of the main wall. Start up a small right facing corner beneath a birch tree at the entrance to a small cave with decent pro. Stem out of the cave, clipping a bolt on the right side to protect the moves over the wedged and stacked blocks. These blocks are not as scary as they look, but care should be taken. Follow the obvious hand crack up to rings on the grassy ledge. (5.9)

P2: Carry on directly above the anchor up the thin crack in the right facing corner through the small roofs. Clip a bolt above the ledge to the right, then trend boldly left to find some more gear around the corner in the blocks (~5.10c)



The crack is obvious when looking at the face from below. Starts about 30m to the right of the Space Quest pillar/chimney

Single rack to 3", doubles in the finger sizes may come in handy but are not necessary

Climb climber's left into the obvious Chimney created by the pillar, trend high and left into the chimney to find the first bolt, at 30ft from the belay. Follow the bolt line up towards the large ledge beneath the overhanging corner. Some small gear can be placed to ease the run-outs between bolts, but this route can be led safely on the bolts alone. 

The main buttress of The Big Choss. The ledge with the steep dihedral is clearly visible from the approach and the pillar/chimney can be found from the base of the wall.
Bolts to rings on the ledge

This is the largest buttress behind the wild cove waste management facility. It is a sprawling area made up of several tiers running to a maximum of 100m. Several routes have been established in a traditional style: ground up, bolting from stances or on hooks and small, marginal pro. Some of the routes, like Shit Hawk (5.10) and Hangover Anxiety (5.9), are relatively clean and protect well with traditional gear, but the climbing should not be taken lightly. This is adventure climbing on rock that ranges from ostensibly good to terrifying choss, much like the climbing in the Canadian Rockies.
